context: <a0_0>Different societies apply differing criteria regarding who is classified as "black"<a0_0/>, and these social constructs have also changed over time. In a number of countries, <a1_0>societal variables<a1_0/> affect classification as much as skin color, and the social criteria for "blackness" vary. For example, in North America the term black people is not necessarily an indicator of skin color or majority ethnic ancestry, but <a3_0>it is instead a socially based racial classification related to being African American, with a family history associated with institutionalized slavery.<a3_0/> In South Africa and Latin America, for instance, <a2_0>mixed-race people are generally not classified as "black."<a2_0/> In South Pacific regions such as Australia and Melanesia, <a4_0>European colonists applied the term "black" or it was used by populations with different histories and ethnic origin.
